programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: J-MELO
programme.desc: Experience the cutting edge of Japanese entertainment as we turn the spotlight on virtual artists. This week, the all-male VTuber group HOLOSTARS. On Demand until April 15, 2026

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: This program is an animation series about a Japanese dog, Charo. He meets and is helped by many mythical creatures of Northern Japan as he searches for eight star talismans.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Sweet potatoes are a popular food throughout Japan. They're baked, simmered, added to soup, and turned into confectionery. Baked sweet potatoes are a beloved street food. Recently, sweet potatoes have also been used for purposes other than food. They've been planted on rooftops to keep buildings cool, and waste material from sweet potatoes has been fermented to produce methane for use in generating electricity. We introduce the increasingly diverse ways in which sweet potatoes are used and sold.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.desc: Kotaro likes to go for walks near the mausoleum for Date Masamune, a famous historical lord. Komimi, who lives in a glass workshop, has a surprising spot where she likes to drink water.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Somewhere Street
programme.desc: Davao, located on Mindanao Island, is home to 1.7 million people. Global business such as call centers are now thriving here. This city is often cited as being one of the safest in the Philippines.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: RAMEN JAPAN
programme.desc: Enjoy Tonkotsu ramen loved by Okayama locals—classic topping: pork cutlet!? Plus a fragrant chicken broth bowl!

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Hina Dolls: In Prayer for Healthy, Happy Children
programme.desc: Hina dolls, which represent the emperor, empress and the imperial court, are presented to girls on the first March 3, Girl's Day celebration after they are born. Beautifully crafted by masters, they embody wishes for the girls to grow up healthy and happy.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.desc: This time: obtaining permission. Tran Van Vuong from Vietnam designs fishing rods at a sports equipment manufacturer. Since transferring to the Japanese headquarters of his company in 2018, Vuong-san has become a popular member of staff. However, when asking for permission, he tends to use "daijoobu," when "yoroshii" would be more appropriate. Vuong-san will tackle a workplace roleplay and learn how to ask for permission. Today's kanji is "sakini." And in "After 5!," we visit a super Sento.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: Judo instructor Sato Hitoe uses worn-out uniforms, or gis, to make items like tote bags; very durable, since the original material was meant to be tough. And behind it all is Sato's love for judo.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Quantum Entanglement - Einstein's Final Mystery
programme.desc: Is quantum entanglement real, or just a misunderstanding? The question confounded Einstein and ruined the lives of many physicists. This is the story of the 100-year mystery that changed physics.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Broadcasters' Eye
programme.sub-title: Invisible Scars: 20 Years since the Deadly Accident
programme.desc: 【Produced by Asahi Television Broadcasting】 The Derailment Accident on the JR Fukuchiyama Line occurred in 2005. This program reveals the invisible scars of those who lost family, endure endless treatment, or search for meaning in surviving.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: ANIME MANGA EXPLOSION
programme.desc: This time, we spotlight sports manga and anime, a genre beloved in Japan and worldwide. How has the portrayal of sports evolved over time, and how have creators refined their craft? We explore those questions with anime critic Fujitsu Ryota. Plus, we visit the production of the figure skating anime Medalist to find out how animators capture the subtle movements and atmosphere of the rink.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.desc: Rockie and her mates begin using "messenger birds" to send messages to each other, but the flat and unemotional relaying by the birds cause critical misunderstandings. Educational theme: Courtesy and morals in communication.

programme.title: Texico
programme.desc: Learn the principles of programming without even touching a computer in this new-style education program. Unique animated characters assist in the fun and lucid introduction of 5 core programming processes: analysis, combination, generalization, abstraction and simulation.

programme.title: Chatroom Japan
programme.sub-title: Can Tradition Inspire a Green Future?
programme.desc: Aditya Sharma seeks a sustainable balance between protecting the planet and meeting consumer demand for clothing. He explores a Japanese tradition in the hopes of finding inspiration.

programme.title: IMPACTS: Climates Change the World
programme.sub-title: On the Brink of Extinction?: Episode 5 Bee Decline and the Looming Food Crisis
programme.desc: Rising temperatures due to climate change have affected the behavior of bees, with fewer bees and shorter pollination periods, posing a threat to agriculture that could lead to a food crisis.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Hokkaido Prefecture / Takeya Takayuki (Model maker) Fishing boats in the herring industry―which thrived here until the 1950s―featured swirling decorations that made a big impression on Takeya, a Hokkaido native.

programme.title: Where We Call Home
programme.sub-title: Keeping the Fires of Tradition Burning
programme.desc: We meet two Americans who preserve Japanese traditions. Chris Hinds ensures the safe conduct of Nozawa Onsen's fire festival in Nagano Prefecture, and Andrew Mancabelli crafts Japanese armor in Warabi, Saitama Prefecture.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.desc: The Murakami Kaizoku were seafarers and fighters in the Seto Inland Sea. We explore their history and legacy, with footage from time-lapse creator Shimizu Daisuke. This time, the Kurushima Straits.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.sub-title: The Evolution of Volcanic Disaster Prediction Technology
programme.desc: Japan is one of the most volcanically active nations. Its world-leading research on volcanic disasters has led to new technologies to track underground magma and predict phreatic eruptions.

programme.title: Activate Your Japanese!
programme.desc: Drama "Xuan Tackles Japan!" Time has passed, and the hotel's autumn campaign has been a success. Rei then tells Xuan that he is quitting his job at the hotel to go to France. Unable to process this sudden revelation, Xuan shrinks from talking to Rei even on the day of his departure. But she knows she needs to talk to him before he leaves, and she hurries after him to the airport. Xuan wants to express her feelings and gratitude to Rei. Will she be able to say what she wants to say? What should she do if she feels unsure of her Japanese? "Onomatopoeia" -Share Feelings- Kotsukotsu

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.sub-title: A Children's Cafe with Foreign Cooks
programme.desc: Efforts to save children have evolved in a unique way, energizing people who provide services. We introduce a splendid international example of such an initiative in Matsuyama, Ehime Prefecture.

programme.title: HELLO! NHK WORLD-JAPAN
programme.desc: In a special feature on Hokkaido, programs looked at the ecology of brown bears, a special bento lunch, and a bountiful landscape formed by rugged natural conditions and pioneering development.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.sub-title: Noboribetsu Onsen: Hot Springs, Spirited People
programme.desc: Located in Hokkaido Prefecture in northern Japan is Noboribetsu, a prominent resort of hot springs, or "onsen" in Japanese. Seven spring sources produce 3,000 liters of hot water every minute at a huge explosion crater called "Jigokudani," Japanese for "Hell Valley." In this episode of Seasoning the Seasons, we invite you to Noboribetsu, a spa resort where the passion of the locals is as hot as the springs.

programme.title: A Culture Built with Wood
programme.desc: The Hida region in Gifu Prefecture has some of the country's most extensive broadleaf forests. Here, local artisans with sophisticated woodworking techniques are referred to as "Hida's Master Craftsmen," a title that has been respected for 1,300 years. Their skills are showcased in the floats of the Takayama Autumn Festival, ranked among the 3 most beautiful festivals in Japan. These floats are crafted using Japanese wood joinery techniques and do not use a single nail. Join us as we examine the craftsmanship that interlocks with the Hida region.

programme.desc: Cancer treatments can leave a patient's fingernails weak and dark, adding to their anxiety. So a doctor opened a nail salon to help clients improve both their appearance and their outlook on life.

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.desc: Hello there! It's me, Tama. Don't mind me, I just saw a hole and wanted to cool my paws in it. Looks like Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko are preparing their annual dried persimmons. So tasty! So sweet! But it takes weeks before they're ready! I don't know if I can wait that long!

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: Akan: The Sacred Winter World of the Ainu
programme.desc: Akan, in eastern Hokkaido, is renowned for its breathtaking winter landscape with majestic volcanic mountains and ice-blanketed lake. Kit Nagamura gets to know some local Ainu people and discovers their deep ties to the natural world.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese people's coexistence with nature has led to many words and expressions related to kusa or "grass" taking root in the Japanese language.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: Gojinjo Taiko is a wild, powerful performance by masked drummers. It originated 400 years ago in the small coastal community of Nafune-machi in Ishikawa Prefecture. The story goes that, faced with an imminent attack by a powerful warlord, villagers used improvised masks to disguise themselves as oni (demons), and scared away the approaching forces. Gojinjo Taiko is performed not only at the summer matsuri (festival) but at local hotels in everyday life, as a form of community revitalization.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: This program is an animation series about a Japanese dog, Charo. He meets and is helped by many mythical creatures of Northern Japan as he searches for eight star talismans.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Sweet potatoes are a popular food throughout Japan. They're baked, simmered, added to soup, and turned into confectionery. Baked sweet potatoes are a beloved street food. Recently, sweet potatoes have also been used for purposes other than food. They've been planted on rooftops to keep buildings cool, and waste material from sweet potatoes has been fermented to produce methane for use in generating electricity. We introduce the increasingly diverse ways in which sweet potatoes are used and sold.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.desc: Kotaro likes to go for walks near the mausoleum for Date Masamune, a famous historical lord. Komimi, who lives in a glass workshop, has a surprising spot where she likes to drink water.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: ANIME MANGA EXPLOSION
programme.desc: This time, we spotlight sports manga and anime, a genre beloved in Japan and worldwide. How has the portrayal of sports evolved over time, and how have creators refined their craft? We explore those questions with anime critic Fujitsu Ryota. Plus, we visit the production of the figure skating anime Medalist to find out how animators capture the subtle movements and atmosphere of the rink.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.desc: Rockie and her mates begin using "messenger birds" to send messages to each other, but the flat and unemotional relaying by the birds cause critical misunderstandings. Educational theme: Courtesy and morals in communication.

programme.title: Texico
programme.desc: Learn the principles of programming without even touching a computer in this new-style education program. Unique animated characters assist in the fun and lucid introduction of 5 core programming processes: analysis, combination, generalization, abstraction and simulation.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Hina Dolls: In Prayer for Healthy, Happy Children
programme.desc: Hina dolls, which represent the emperor, empress and the imperial court, are presented to girls on the first March 3, Girl's Day celebration after they are born. Beautifully crafted by masters, they embody wishes for the girls to grow up healthy and happy.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.desc: This time: obtaining permission. Tran Van Vuong from Vietnam designs fishing rods at a sports equipment manufacturer. Since transferring to the Japanese headquarters of his company in 2018, Vuong-san has become a popular member of staff. However, when asking for permission, he tends to use "daijoobu," when "yoroshii" would be more appropriate. Vuong-san will tackle a workplace roleplay and learn how to ask for permission. Today's kanji is "sakini." And in "After 5!," we visit a super Sento.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: Judo instructor Sato Hitoe uses worn-out uniforms, or gis, to make items like tote bags; very durable, since the original material was meant to be tough. And behind it all is Sato's love for judo.

Plus, we visit the production of the figure skating anime Medalist to find out how animators capture the subtle movements and atmosphere of the rink.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends

programme.title: Texico
programme.desc: Learn the principles of programming without even touching a computer in this new-style education program. Unique animated characters assist in the fun and lucid introduction of 5 core programming processes: analysis, combination, generalization, abstraction and simulation.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: Akan: The Sacred Winter World of the Ainu
programme.desc: Akan, in eastern Hokkaido, is renowned for its breathtaking winter landscape with majestic volcanic mountains and ice-blanketed lake. programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: Gojinjo Taiko is a wild, powerful performance by masked drummers. It originated 400 years ago in the small coastal community of Nafune-machi in Ishikawa Prefecture. The story goes that, faced with an imminent attack by a powerful warlord, villagers used improvised masks to disguise themselves as oni (demons), and scared away the approaching forces. Gojinjo Taiko is performed not only at the summer matsuri (festival) but at local hotels in everyday life, as a form of community revitalization.
